title: I just found out the morning that I owe $42000 to Sallie Mae what are my options?
question: Unknown to me my husband co-signed on my daughter's student loans. He died 7 years ago and said they were not informed. My daughter said they were.She has been paying the loan off for the last 7 years, now they want payment. What are my options and legal rights? Do I need to hire someone to negotiate?
answers: You are not liable for your late spouse's debt for a co-signed student loan debt. Of course if there was an estate probated they can file a claim. If there is a probate case discuss this with your lawyer.

It is very important that you get legal assistance right away if Sallie Mae is alleging you owe any sums of money. If you did not co-sign, you are not legally responsible. Most (not all) school loans that have a co-signers are private loans, not federal. Also it looks like there is some issue as to when the last payment was made. Again, if this is private loan, the statute of limitations is 4 years which means if no payment was made in the last 4 years, they can no longer sue on it. Also be advised that Sallie Mae loans can be private, As far as your options you should first determine the type of loan and your legal responsibility. Unfortunately, you cannot trust the collector to tell you what is really going on. If the loan is Federal, you have a whole host of other issues you must consider. Again, you should get legal counsel right away.

If you want to discuss your case further, please contact me at 855-709-5788 or at gfitzgerald@fclawoffice.com. We only represents consumers in CA. Every case is unique and requires a thorough analysis of your situation with a lawyer

You are not liable for your husband's debts whether deceased or even if he were still here. I would call around to several attorneys in your area that work in this practice area (debt/collection lawyers) and get some specific insights. But I am not so sure they have any recourse against you at this point and really would have to seek a remedy against your daughter. Further, it is not clear that you are in default here.

Please get proper and actionable advice before saying anything further to the lender.

Best regards,
Frank
Natoli-Lapin, LLC
